events: Spring – A severe Black Death epidemic begins in the Crimea.[1]
March 18 – The French prepare to defend the channel coasts.[2]
April 1–August 20 – Siege of Aiguillon: The French fail to take Aiguillon from its English defenders.[2]
April 16 – The Serbian Empire is proclaimed in Skopje by Dusan Silni, occupying much of South-Eastern Europe.[3]
May–June – An English invasion fleet assembles at Portsmouth.[2]
June 9 – Battle of St Pol de Léon: The English army defeats Charles of Blois in Brittany.[2]
June 20 – The English win a small victory at La Roche-Derrien in Brittany.[2]
June 24 – The leaders of Ghent, Bruges and Ypres agree to support Edward III.[2]
July – Edward III orders the closing of English ports to stop information from reaching France.[2]
July 3 – The English fleet attempts to sail from Portsmouth to Normandy, but is forced back by contrary winds.[2]
July 11 – Charles IV, Count of Luxembourg and King of Bohemia, is elected King of the Romans.[4]
July 11–12 – Edward III and the English army cross the English Channel and begin an invasion of France.[5]
July 12–18 – The English raid and burn neighbouring towns and villages in the Cotentin Peninsula.[5]
July 26 – Battle of Caen (1346): an English army captures and sacks the French city of Caen.[6]
August 10 – Jaume Ferrer sets out from Majorca for the "River of Gold", the Senegal River.[7]
August 24 – Battle of Blanchetaque: The English defeat the French.
August 26 – Battle of Crécy: The English defeat the French, in the first European battle where gunpowder is used.[8]
September 4 – The English begin the siege of Calais.[8]
September–October – Anglo-Gascon offensives overrun large parts of south west France.[9]
October 4 – The English capture and sack the French city of Poitiers.[10]
October 17 – Battle of Neville's Cross: The English army defeats the Scots.[11]
October–November – Several Mongol towns in the Crimea are cleared of inhabitants by the Black Death.[1]
Repairs are made in the Hagia Sophia.
Asia[edit]
Europe[edit]
births: July 20 – Margaret, Countess of Pembroke, English princess, daughter of King Edward III of England (d. 1361)[40]
date unknown – Eustache Deschamps, French poet (d. 1406)[41]
deaths: March 28 – Venturino of Bergamo, Dominican preacher (b. 1304)[43]
August – Muhammad Aytimur, leader of the Sarbadars of Sabzewar (alternative date is September)[44]

August 26 (killed in the Battle of Crécy):
Charles II, Count of Alençon (b. 1297)[45]
Louis I, Count of Flanders (b. 1304)[46]
Louis II, Count of Blois
John of Bohemia (b. 1296)[4]
Rudolph, Duke of Lorraine (b. 1320)[47]
October – Raghnall Mac Ruaidhrí, Scottish magnate

October 17 (killed in the Battle of Neville's Cross):
John Randolph, 3rd Earl of Moray[48]
Maurice de Moravia, Earl of Strathearn[49]
Maurice de Moravia, Earl of Strathearn[49]
November 14 – Ostasio I da Polenta, Lord of Ravenna (assassinated)[50]
November 27 – Saint Gregory of Sinai (b. c. 1260)[51]

date unknown
Eustace Folville, English outlaw[52]
Hélion de Villeneuve, Grand Master of the Knights of St John[53]
Hélion de Villeneuve, Grand Master of the Knights of St John[53]
